issues.description: Template repository has a method-name mismatch for accessing the ingredient quantity: Stock.java calls getQuantity() (e.g., when adding/taking ingredients), but StockIngredient.java in the template exposes retrieveQuantity() instead of getQuantity(). This breaks the expected getter naming convention requested in the problem statement ("add getters for all the private fields") and causes compilation errors or confusion for students when they try to use the provided Stock methods. The solution repository consistently uses getQuantity(), so the template deviates from the intended API.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name in the template StockIngredient with the rest of the code and the typical Java getter convention. Rename retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() (returning int), or alternatively update Stock.java to call retrieveQuantity() everywhere. The preferred fix is to rename retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/StockIngredient.java so the template, the problem statement's getter instruction, and the solution all use the same API.

issues.description: The template defines the quantity getter for StockIngredient as retrieveQuantity(), while the template's Stock and Main classes (and the solution) use getQuantity(). The problem statement also asks students to “add getters for all the private fields,” which commonly implies the getX() naming convention. This inconsistent naming across artifacts (template vs. solution/problem expectations) creates mapping confusion and can cause compilation errors or wasted time as students try to determine which getter name to implement/use.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template's StockIngredient.retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() (and keep its semantics), and update any references if necessary. Ensure getter naming follows the getX() convention so the template, problem instructions, and solution use a consistent identifier (getQuantity).
